awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Computation of Functional Relations among Solutions of Difference and Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The pull of Earth's gravity on a satellite produces acceleration, which affects the satellite's velocity and position, making its orbit an ellipse.  This is just one example of a mathematical phenomenon that arises from constraints on a physical system that can be modeled by differential or difference equations.  This project will develop algorithms to automatically uncover the algebraic properties of functions defined by differential or difference equations by looking for symmetries.  It will produce publicly-available implementations that will be useful to researchers in different areas, such as physics, number theory, and combinatorics. Key components of this project include the fostering of interactions with other scientific fields and the advancement of international collaborations. 

The key to this project's approach for discovering the functional relations among the solutions of differential or difference equations is that these relations are encoded in the algebraic structure of a corresponding Galois group. This project will develop algorithms that determine, 1) for a linear differential equation with continuous or discrete parameters, which additional functional equations are satisfied by the solutions; 2) for a linear difference equation with respect to a shift, q-dilation, Mahler, or elliptic curve addition, which differential equations are satisfied by the solutions; and 3) for a linear difference equation with respect to a q-dilation or Mahler p-operator, which additional difference equations with respect to a q'-dilation or Mahler p'-operator, respectively, are satisfied by the solutions. In each of these three situations there is a Galois theory that encodes the sought properties of the solutions. Algorithms to compute the corresponding Galois groups lead directly to procedures to compute the functional relations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Differential and difference equations arise in many different areas within the physical sciences and mathematics, for example Number Theory, Combinatorics, and Mathematical Physics, to name a few. The physical or mathematical laws governing the behavior of a system are often modeled by differential or difference equations. Given such an equation, the most immediate goal is to try to ?solve it?, which usually means to obtain a concrete formula that can answer any question one might have about the system: its past, its present state, and its future. In practice, it is not always possible to completely solve these kinds of equations, in which case the researcher would like to know what properties these unknown solutions have, even if a concrete formula for them remains elusive.

The overall goal of this project was to develop algorithmic tools to discover the properties of solutions of certain kinds of differential equations and difference equations. The key theoretical tool underpinning these algorithmic developments is Galois theory, which is designed to exploit the symmetries inherent in the equation itself to deduce the sought properties of its solutions. This project was successful in developing a collection of algorithmic results in support of this goal. The results obtained were published in high-caliber international academic journals and disseminated at local, national, and international conferences, to audiences consisting of specialists, general scientific practicioners, and graduate and undergraduate students in mathematics and the physical sciences.

Some of the main specific results produced by this project are the following:

  • A set of criteria that allow one to deduce that the solutions of certain kinds of difference equations (including all the special cases mentioned above) do not in turn satisfy any differential equations at all. These criteria were successfully applied to the so-called elliptic hypergeometric functions, which were introduced in the early 2000s by the mathematical physics community to model many different kinds of phenomena, for example the entropy in the event horizon of a black hole. The applicability of our criteria to elliptic hypergeometric functions stems from the fact that they are known to satisfy elliptic difference equations.
  • An algorithm to compute all the differential equations that are or are not satisfied by solutions to q-difference equations of small order. These q-difference equations arise in many different contexts. With this algorithm, a scientist wishing to understand some phenomena modeled by q-difference equations might be able to obtain automatically useful information about its solutions. We showcased one such application within Knot Theory.
  • The development of a theoretical and technical notion of residue for the Mahler difference context. Mahler equations arise in particular within Automata Theory, in the study of so-called automatic sequences. This new notion of Mahler residues behaves analogously to earlier notions of residue developed by other researchers in other contexts (such as shift difference equations and q-difference equations), whose absence in the Mahler context has been a roadblock in the development of algorithmic tools similar to the ones that already exist for shift and q-difference equations. This tool will prove essential in further computational advances concerning Mahler difference equations.

This project supported the mentorship of one postdoctoral researcher, who was one of the main contributors to some of the specific results mentioned above, and two PhD students (in the form of graduate research assistantships), one of whom develops and implements in a computer algebra system an algorithm to compute discrete residues in the shift case, whereas the other is developing an algorithm to compute Galois groups for elliptic difference equations.

This project also supported the PI?s participation as an instructor in a summer school for Latin American and Caribbean undergraduate students, where he taught a week-long course in Spanish introducing these students to some of the main themes and tools involved in the Galois-theoretic study of differential equations. Underdeveloped regions, such as Latin America, are rife with academic potential and raw talent ? such programs help bridge some of the challenges in enabling these students to enhance the academic atmosphere of US institutions by choosing to attend graduate school here.
